question: A bivalent metal has an equivalent mass of 32. The molecular mass of the metal nitrate is
question_latex: A bivalent metal has an equivalent mass of 32. The molecular mass of the metal nitrate is
solution: \text{(d) Atomic mass of the metal} = 32 \times 2 = 64 \newline \text{Formula of metal nitrate} = M(NO_3)_2 \newline \text{Molecular mass} = 64 + 28 + 96 = 188

question: What amount of calcium oxide will be produced by decomposition of 10 g calcium carbonate?
question_latex: What amount of calcium oxide will be produced by decomposition of 10 g calcium carbonate?
solution: CaCO_3 \rightarrow CaO + CO_2 \newline \frac{100 g}{56 g} \newline \text{10 g of calcium carbonate produces 5.6 g of calcium oxide.}

ewline = 145.4

question: Find the number of hydrogen atoms present in 6.0 g of H₂O C N H₂ . [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Find the number of hydrogen atoms present in 6.0\, \text{g of } H_2O\, C\, N\, H_2 . \text{ [MHT-CET 2022]}
solution: 60 g of urea contains \( 4 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} \) atoms of Hydrogen.\\\(\therefore\, 6.0 \, \text{g of urea contains } = \frac{6 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23}}{60} = 2.4 \times 10^{23}\, \text{atoms of Hydrogen}\)

question: A 400 mg iron capsule contains 100 mg of ferrous fumarate, (CHCOO)₂Fe. the percentage of iron present in it is approximately
question_latex: A 400 \, \text{mg iron capsule contains 100 mg of ferrous fumarate, } (CHCOO)_2Fe.\, \text{the percentage of iron present in it is approximately}
solution: Molecular mass of \((CHCOO)_2Fe = 170\)\\In 100 g \((CHCOO)_2Fe\), iron present \(= \frac{56}{170} \times 100 \text{ mg}\)\\\(= 32.9\, \text{mg}\)\\Since, this quantity of Fe is present in 400 mg of capsule,\\\(\therefore\, \text{% of Fe in capsule }= \frac{32.9}{400} \times 100 = 8.2\%\)

question: Calculate mass in kg of 2.5 mole ammonia. [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Calculate \text{ mass in kg of 2.5 mole ammonia. [MHT-CET 2024]}
solution: 1 mole of \(NH_3 = 17 \times 10^{-3}\, \text{ kg }\)\\2.5 mole of \(NH_3 = 17 \times 10^{-3} \times 2.5 = 4.25 \times 10^{-2} \text{ kg}\)

question: Camphor is often used in molecular mass determination because
question_latex: Camphor is often used in molecular mass determination because
options: (B) It has a very high cryoscopic constant
(D) It is solvent for organic substances
solution: Solution:-(c) Camphor is used in molecular mass determination due to volatile nature. The method is called Rast s camphor method. Camphor acts as a solid solvent which is volatile, hence can be removed easily.

question: At constant temperature and pressure when 8 volumes of dihydrogen gas react with 4 volumes of dioxygen, the mass of water vapour produced is
question_latex: At constant temperature and pressure when 8 volumes of dihydrogen gas react with 4 volumes of dioxygen, the mass of water vapour produced is
solution:
Solution:: $$2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(g)\rightarrow mol \ 1 \ mol 2 \ mol$$  
\[8 \ mol \ 4 \ mol \ 8 \ mol \text{Mass of } H_2O(g) =  \text{no. of moles} \ \times \ \text{molar mass} \]

$$=8 \times 18 = 144 \ g$$

question: An aromatic hydrocarbon with empirical formula $$C_5H_4$$ on treatment with concentrated $$H_2SO_4$$ gave a monosulphonic acid. 0.104 g of the acid required 10 mL of \( \frac{N}{20} \) NaOH for complete neutralisation. The molecular formula of hydrocarbon is
question_latex: An aromatic hydrocarbon with empirical formula $$C_5H_4$$ on treatment with concentrated $$H_2SO_4$$ gave a monosulphonic acid. 0.104 g of the acid required 10 mL of \( \frac{N}{20} \) NaOH for complete neutralisation. The molecular formula of hydrocarbon is
solution:
Solution:-(c) An aromatic hydrocarbon (empirical formula $$C_5H_4$$ ) $$+H_2SO_4 \rightarrow$$ monosulphonic acid $$\therefore 0.104 g $$ of monosulphonic acid required $10 \ \text{mL}$ of  $$\frac{N}{20} NaOH $$ for complete neutralisation \[\therefore \frac{0.104}{32} \times \frac{1}{20} \times 10^{-3} \] 
$$n = 3.25 \text{ X }  3 = 24 $$
The molecular formula of hydrocarbon will be $$C_{15}H_{12}$$ .

question: Which property of an element is always a whole number?
question_latex: Which property of an element is always a whole number?
solution: Solution:-Atomic number is a whole number whereas atomic mass, atomic radius, and atomic volume can have fractional values. For example, the atomic number of hydrogen is 1 and that of helium is 2. The atomic mass of hydrogen is 1.008 u.

question: Number of atoms of He in 100 u of He (atomic weight of He is 4) are
question_latex: Number of atoms of He in 100 u of He (atomic weight of He is 4) are
solution: Solution:-(a)  \[ \frac{4}{4}  \ u  = 1 \ \text{He atom} \] \[ \therefore \ 1 \ u = \frac{1}{4} \text{He atom} \] Hence, 100 u =  \[ \frac{1 \ x \ 100}{4} = 25 \ \text{atoms} \]

question: There are two isotopes of an element with atomic mass $$z$$ . Heavier one has atomic mass $$z + 2$$ and lighter one has $$z - 1$$ , the abundance of lighter one is
question_latex: There are two isotopes of an element with atomic mass $$z$$ . Heavier one has atomic mass $$z + 2$$ and lighter one has $$z - 1$$ , the abundance of lighter one is
solution:
Solution:-(a) Let the percent abundance of lighter isotope is $x$ . $$\therefore \text{Atomic mass, } z = \frac{x(z-1)+(100-x)(z+2)}{z+100-x} $$ 
$$3x = 200 \text{ or } x = 66.6 \%$$

question: The volume of 1 mole of any pure gas at standard temperature and pressure is always equal to
question_latex: The volume of 1 mole of any pure gas at standard temperature and pressure is always equal to
solution: Solution:-(B)

question: How many atoms of Argon are present in 52 mole of it? [Atomic mass of Ar = 39 ]
question_latex: How many atoms of Argon are present in 52 mole of it? [Atomic mass of Ar = 39 ]
solution:
Solution:-(a) 1 mole of Ar = $$39 \ g $$ of Ar
$$=6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ atoms of Ar}$$ 
$$\therefore \ 52 \text{ mole of Ar} = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \times 52$$ 
$$= 3.13 \times 10^{25} \text{ atoms of Ar } \ $$

question: A sample of calcium carbonate has the following percentage composition. Ca=40%,C=12% and O=48%According to law of definite proportion the weight of calcium in 4g of a sample of calcium carbonate from another source will be (At.No.:Ca=40,C=12,O=16 )
question_latex: A sample of calcium carbonate has the following percentage composition. Ca=40%,C=12% and O=48%According to law of definite proportion the weight of calcium in 4g of a sample of calcium carbonate from another source will be (At.No.:Ca=40,C=12,O=16 )
solution: Solution:-(A)In $$100 \ g \text{ of } CaCO_3, 40 \ g Ca \text{ is present.} \therefore \text{In 4 \ g of } CaCO_3 = \frac{4 \times 40}{100}  = 1.6 \ g$$

question: Which from following quantity of different gases contains maximum number of molecules?
question_latex: Which from following quantity of different gases contains maximum number of molecules?
solution:
Solution:-(c) Number of molecules \[= \text{Number of moles} \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} \]
Number of molecules \[\times\text{Number of moles} \]
(A) $$N_2 = \frac{7}{28} \equiv 0.25 \ mol $$
(B) $$O_2 = \frac{8}{32}  = 1 \ mol $$
(C) $$H_2 \ = \  \frac{2}{2}  \equiv 0.25 \ mol $$
(D) $$NO_2 = \frac{20}{46} = 0.43 \ mol $$
Thus, $$H_2$$ amognst given  $$2 \ g H_2$$ gas will contain maximum number of molecules.

question: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
question_latex: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
solution: Solution:-(C) Law of multiple proportions is applicable for two or more elements are combined in more than one form.e.g. $$ H_2O,H_2O_2; SO_2; SO_3; NO; NO_2$$

question: The volume of oxygen required for complete combustion of 0.25 mole of methane at S.T.P. is
question_latex: The volume of oxygen required for complete combustion of 0.25 mole of methane at S.T.P. is
solution: Solution:-(C) $$CH_4 + 2O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + 2H_2O $$  1 mole of methane required \[= 2 \times 22.4 \text{ dm}^3 \]  \[\therefore \ O_2:0.25 \text{ mole of methane required} =  2 \times 22.4 \times 0.25 = 11.2 \text{ dm}^3 \ of \ O_2$$

question: Calculate number of molecules present in 5.4 g of urea (Molar mass of urea = $$60 g mol^{-1}$$)
question_latex: Calculate number of molecules present in 5.4 g of urea (Molar mass of urea = $$60 g mol^{-1}$$)
solution:
Solution:-(c) Given : $$ n_A  = \frac{W}{MW} = \frac{N}{n_A} $$
\[1 \ \text{mol urea} = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \ \text{molecules}$$

\text{No. of molecules in 5.4 g of urea} \]

 \[= \frac{5.4 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23}}{60 \ \text{mol}^{-1}} = 5.4 \times 10^{22} \text{ molecules} \]

question: A mixture of $$CaCl_2$$ and NaCl weighing 4.44 g is treated with sodium carbonate solution to precipitate all the $$Ca^{2+}$$ ions as calcium carbonate. The calcium carbonate so obtained is heated strongly to get 0.56 g of CaO. The percentage of NaCl in the mixture (atomic mass of Ca = 40 ) is
question_latex: A mixture of $$CaCl_2$$ and NaCl weighing 4.44 g is treated with sodium carbonate solution to precipitate all the $$Ca^{2+}$$ ions as calcium carbonate. The calcium carbonate so obtained is heated strongly to get 0.56 g of CaO. The percentage of NaCl in the mixture (atomic mass of Ca = 40 ) is
solution:
Solution:-(a) $$CaCO_3 \rightarrow CaO + CO_2$$
1 mol 1 mol \[CaCl_2 +  Na_2CO_3 \rightarrow CaCO_3 + 2 Na_2 \] 1 mol 1 mol 
1 mol 1 mol$CaCl_2 \rightarrow CaCO_3 + 2 Na_2$$\] 1 mol 1 mol $CaCl_2 = 0.01 \times 111 \ g \ CaCl_2$$ = 1.11 \g \ C\l CaCl_2$$ \therefore\text{in the mixture, weight of NaCl= \[4.44 - 1.11 = 3.33 \ g  \]
\text{Percentage of }CaCl_2 = \frac{3.33}{4.44} \times 100 = 75%$$

question: What quantity of oxygen is required for the complete combustion of 100 ml ethane under constant temperature and pressure?
question_latex: What quantity of oxygen is required for the complete combustion of 100 ml ethane under constant temperature and pressure?
solution:
Solution:-(a)  \[C_2H_6(g) + 3.5O_2(g)\rightarrow 2CO_2(g) + 3H_2O(g)\]
1 vol . of ethane reacts with 3.5 vol . of oxygen. \[\therefore 100ml \text{ of } ethane\] will require 350 ml of oxygen for the complete combustion.

question: What is the average mass of an element if it has two isotopes, one of mass 6.015u with 8.24% and other of mass 7.016u with 91.26% respectively?
question_latex: What is the average mass of an element if it has two isotopes, one of mass 6.015u with 8.24\% and other of mass 7.016u with 91.26\% respectively?
solution:
Solution:-(D) Average isotopic mass $$= \frac{8.24}{100} \times 6.015 + \frac{91.26}{100} \times 7.016$$
\[=0.496 + 6.403 = 6.899u\]

question: Mass of one molecule of oxygen in amu and in gram respectively is
question_latex: Mass of one molecule of oxygen in amu and in gram respectively is
solution:
Solution:-(c) Molecular mass of $$O_2 = 2 \times 16u = 32u$$
$$\therefore \ \text{Mass of 1 molecule of } O_2$$  
$$= 32 \times 1.6605 \times 10^{-24} g = 53.1379 \times 10^{-24}g$$

question: Find out number of carbon atoms present in 0.35 mole of glucose.
question_latex: Find out number of carbon atoms present in 0.35 mole of glucose.
solution:
Solution:-(c) 1 mole glucose $$= 6.022 \times 10^{23} 	ext{ molecules of glucose } (C_6H_{12}O_6)$$
\[0.35 \text{ moles of glucose } =  \ 0.35 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 2.1077 \times 10^{23}  \]
Since, 1 molecule of glucose contains 6 carbon atoms
Therefore, $$2.1077\times 10^{23} \text{ molecules of glucose contain } 6 \times 2.1077 \times 10^{23} = 1.2646 \times 10^{24} \text{ carbon atoms.}$$

question: What is the number of hydrogen atoms present in 5.4 g of urea?
question_latex: What is the number of hydrogen atoms present in 5.4 g of urea?
solution:
Solution:-(d) 1 mol urea $$= 60 \ g urea \left (  H_{2}	ext {N — CO — NH}_{2} \right ) \text{No. of moles of urea} \ = \  \frac{54}{60} \equiv 0.09 \ 	ext{mol} $$
No. of \[\text{H - atoms in 1 urea molecule} = 4  \]
$$\therefore \text{ H -atom in 0.09 mol urea molecule } = 0.09 \times 4 \ \equiv 0.36 \ 	ext{mol} $$ 
$$\therefore \text{ No. of \ H - atoms in } 0.36 \text{moles} \ = 
0.36 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 2.168 \times 10^{23}$$

question: Calculate the number of molecules in 44.8 cm$$^3$$ of nitrogen gas at STP.
question_latex: Calculate the number of molecules in 44.8 cm$$^3$$ of nitrogen gas at STP.

question: If $$H_2SO_4$$ ionises as $$H_2SO_4 + 2H_2O \rightarrow 2H_3O^+ + SO_4^{2-}$$, then total number of ions produced by 0.1 M $$H_2SO_4$$ will be
question_latex: If $$H_2SO_4$$ ionises as $$H_2SO_4 + 2H_2O \rightarrow 2H_3O^+ + SO_4^{2-}$$, then total number of ions produced by 0.1 M $$H_2SO_4$$ will be
solution:
Solution:-(d) 1 mole of $$H_2SO_4\text{ gives} = 3 \text{ moles of ions or } 3 \times 6.023\times 10^{23} \text{ ions}$$\[\therefore \ 0.1 \ \text{mole of }H_2SO_4 \text{will give} = 0.1 \times 3 \times 6.023\times 10^{23} \text{ ions} \]  
$$= 1.8 \times 10^{23} \text{ ions }$$

question: The number of sodium atoms in 2 moles of sodium ferrocyanide is
question_latex: The number of sodium atoms in 2 moles of sodium ferrocyanide is

question: What is the average mass of an element if it has two isotopes, one of mass 6.015u with 8.24% and other of mass 7.016u with 91.26% respectively?
question_latex: What is the average mass of an element if it has two isotopes, one of mass 6.015u with 8.24\% and other of mass 7.016u with 91.26\% respectively?
solution:
Solution:-(D)  Average isotopic mass $$= \frac{8.24}{100}\times 6.015 + \frac{91.26}{100}\times 7.016$$
$$ = 0.496 + 6.403 = 6.899u$$

question: Air contains 20%$$O_2$$ by volume. How much volume of air will be required for 100 cc of acetylene?
question_latex: Air contains 20\%$$O_2$$ by volume. How much volume of air will be required for 100 cc of acetylene?
solution:
Solution:-(d) $$2C_2H_2 + 5O_2 \rightarrow 4CO_2 + 2H_2O$$ 
$$2 \text{ cc 5 cc} \] $$ \text{100 cc 250 cc}  $$\]
$$ Hence, air will be needed = \frac{100}{{20}} \times 250 \equiv 1250 cc $$

question: If 20 g of $$CaCO_3$$ is treated with 100 mL of 20% $$HCl$$ solution, the amount of $$CO_2$$ produced is
question_latex: If 20 g of $$CaCO_3$$ is treated with 100 mL of 20\% $$HCl$$ solution, the amount of $$CO_2$$ produced is
solution:
Solution:-(b)  \[ CaCO_3 + 2HCl \rightarrow CaCl_2 + CO_2 + H_2O \]
100g \ 9 \ CaCO_3 $$\rightarrow $$ 44g  
$$\text{100 mL of } \ 20\% \ HCl\ \approx\ \text{20 g of } \ HCl\ $$
In this case, $$CaCO_3$$ is the limiting reactant.
$$\therefore 100 \ g \text{ of } CaCO_3  \text{ gives } CO_2 = \frac{44	ext {g}}{100 \text{g}} $$ \ \
$$\therefore 20 \text{ g of } CaCO_3 \text{ will give } CO_2 = \frac{44 \times 20}{100}= 8.80 \ \text{g}$$

question: What is the mass of 33.6dm$$^3$$ of methane gas at STP?
question_latex: What is the mass of 33.6dm$$^3$$ of methane gas at STP?
solution: Solution:-(c) $$22.4\text{dm}^3 \text{ of } CH_4 \text{ is at  STP }$$ \therefore  \ .\ \text{33.6dm}^3 \text{ of } CH_4 = \frac{16 \times 33.6}{22.4} \equiv 24 \g $$ \ \therefore \ \ = 2.4 \times 10^{-2} \text{ kg }$$ \

question: What is the percentage by mass of oxygen in water, if percentage by mass of hydrogen is 11.1% ?
question_latex: What is the percentage by mass of oxygen in water, if percentage by mass of hydrogen is 11.1\% ?
solution:
Solution:-(a) Molecular formula of water = $$H_2O$$
Mass \% of oxygen in water $$ = 100 \ - \ \text{ mass} \% \ \text{of hydrogen in water} \ = 100 \ - 11.1 = 88.9\% $$

question: How many molecules of carbon dioxide are formed when 0.6 g carbon is burnt in air?
question_latex: How many molecules of carbon dioxide are formed when 0.6 g carbon is burnt in air?
solution: Solution:-(a) \text{ C + O }  \rightarrow \text{ CO}_2 \ \[12 \ g  \rightarrow  44 \ g \text{ of } CO_2 \ \equiv 6.022 \times 10^{23}\text{  molecules of } CO_2  \ \therefore 0.6 \ g \text{of carbon } = \frac{6.022\}\ \times 10^{23} \times 0.6 = 3.01 \times 10^{22} \text{molecules of } CO_2 \]

question: One gram mole of a gas at NTP occupies 22.4 L. This fact was derived from

question: What is the number of molecules of nitrogen gas present in 22.4 cm$$^3$$ at STP?
question_latex: What is the number of molecules of nitrogen gas present in 22.4 cm$$^3$$ at STP?
solution:
Solution:-(c) \[ 1 \text{ mole} =22.4\text {dm}^3\text {of } \text {gas} \] $$
\ \=[\ \text{1 cm}^3 = 10^{-3}\ \text{dm}^3 \ \therefore \ \text{22.4 cm}^3 \text { nitrogen gas } \ 
\ =6.022 \times 10^{20}\ \text{ moles} = 6.022 \times 10^{23}$

question: Find the number of moles of sodium atoms in $$6.9 \times 10^{-2}$$ kg of it. [Atomic mass = $$23 g mol^{-1}$$ ]
question_latex: Find the number of moles of sodium atoms in $$6.9 \times 10^{-2}$$ kg of it. [Atomic mass = $$23 g mol^{-1}$$ ]
solution: Solution:-(d) 23 g of Na = 1 \ mol \text{ Na atoms } $$\therefore \text{ 6.9} \times 10^{-2} = 69  \ g \text { of Na}  = \frac{69}{23}$$ \= 3 \text {mol \ of \ Na atoms}$$\end{large}$$

question: If 0.5 mole of $$BaCl_2$$ is mixed with 0.2 mole of $$Na_3PO_4$$ , the maximum number of moles of $$Ba_3(PO_4)_2$$ that can be formed is
question_latex: If 0.5 mole of $$BaCl_2$$ is mixed with 0.2 mole of $$Na_3PO_4$$ , the maximum number of moles of $$Ba_3(PO_4)_2$$ that can be formed is
solution:
Solution:-(d) $$3BaCl_2 + 2Na_3PO_4 \rightarrow  Ba_3(PO_4)_2 + 6NaCl $$
Here, $$Na_3PO_4 $$ is the limiting reactant.
$$2 \ \text{moles of}  \ Na_3PO_{4} \text{gives 1} \ \text{mole of } Ba_3(PO_4)_2 $$
So, $$0.2 \ \text{mole of} \ Na_3PO_{4}\text{ will give}   0.1 \ \text{mole of } \ {{Ba_3(PO_4)_2}}. $$

question_latex: The numerical value of $$\frac{N}{n}$$ (where, $$N$$ is the number of molecules in a given sample of gas and $$n$$ is the number of moles of the gas) is

$$n  \ \text{(no. of moles)} \equiv n \times 6.022\times 10^{23}$$

question: The formula mass of Mohr's salt is 392. The iron present in it is oxidised by $$KMnO_4$$ in acid medium. The equivalent mass of Mohr's salt is
question_latex: The formula mass of Mohr's salt is 392. The iron present in it is oxidised by $$KMnO_4$$ in acid medium. The equivalent mass of Mohr's salt is
solution:
Solution:-(a) Mohr s salt is $$(NH_4)_2SO_4 . FeSO_4 .6H_2O$$
The equation is
\[5Fe^{2+} + MnO_{4-} + 8H^+ \rightarrow 5Fe^{3+} + Mn^{2+} + 4H_2O \] 
Total change in oxidation number of iron 
 $$=+3)-(2) \equiv &+1, \text{So, equivalent wt. of Mohr's salt: }$$

$$eq: wt. Mohr's = \frac{\text { wt. of Mohr's}}{no. of moles}$$ \n$$=\frac {392}{1} = 1 = \frac{392}{1} =\ \equation {392}$$\n$$=\frac {392}{1} = \frac{1}{1}$$
$$\text{})$$

question: Which has maximum number of atoms?
question_latex: Which has maximum number of atoms?

$$^{=} 9.632 x 10^{24}$$

 $$^{=} = 3.612 \times { \text{ }10^{2}\}$$

$$=3.612\times 10^{23}$$

question: $$KMnO_4$$ (mol.wt.= 158) oxidizes oxalic acid in acid medium to $$CO_2$$ and water as follows $$5C_2O_4^{2-} + 2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ \rightarrow 10CO_2 + 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O$$ What is the equivalent weight of $$KMnO_4$$ ?
question_latex: $$KMnO_4$$ (mol.wt.= 158) oxidizes oxalic acid in acid medium to $$CO_2$$ and water as follows $$5C_2O_4^{2-} + 2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ \rightarrow 10CO_2 + 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O$$ What is the equivalent weight of $$KMnO_4$$ ?
solution:
Solution:-(b) $$KMnO_4$$ (mol.wt.= 158) oxidizes oxalic acid in acid medium to $$CO_2$$ and water as follows $$5C_2O_4^{2-} + 2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ \rightarrow 10CO_2 + 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O$$ 
Equivalent weight $$\frac{molecular \text{weight}}{change \text{in oxidation number}} = \frac{158}{5}= 31.6$$

question: How many atoms of argon are present in 3.99g of it? (Atomic mass=39.9)
question_latex: How many atoms of argon are present in 3.99g of it? (Atomic mass=39.9)
solution:
Solution:-(A) Mass of $$Ar = 3.99 \text{g}$$ Atomic mass $$= 39.9$$
\[
\text{Moles of Ar}= \frac{3.99}{3.99} = 0.1 \text{ mol }\text{of Ar} = 6.022 \times 10^{23}\ \text{atoms.} \therefore \text{0.1 } \text{ mol of Ar} = 6.022 \times 1022 \text{atoms}  \ \]

question: The number of significant figures in Avogadro's number is
question_latex: The number of significant figures in Avogadro's number is
solution: When numbers are written in scientific notation, then the number of digits between 1 and 10 gives the number of significant figures. Thus, the number of significant figures in $$6.022 \times 10^{23}$$ is 4.

question: The reaction of calcium with water is represented by the equation, $$ \text{Ca} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{Ca(OH)}_2 + \text{H}_2 $$ What volume of $$ \text{H}_2 $$ at STP would be liberated when 8 g of calcium completely reacts with water?
question_latex: The reaction of calcium with water is represented by the equation, $$ \text{Ca} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{Ca(OH)}_2 + \text{H}_2 $$ What volume of $$ \text{H}_2 $$ at STP would be liberated when 8 g of calcium completely reacts with water?
solution: $$\text{Ca} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{Ca(OH)}_2 + \text{H}_2$$\[22400\text{ cm}^3 \]\[8\text{ g of calcium will produce } \frac{22400\times8}{40} = 4480 \text{ cm}^3 \]

question: The equivalent weight of a certain trivalent element is 20. Molecular weight of its oxide is
question_latex: The equivalent weight of a certain trivalent element is 20. Molecular weight of its oxide is
solution: Atomic weight of element, $$M =$$ equivalent weight $$\times$$ valency \[= 20 \times 3 = 60\]Molecular formula of its oxide= $$M_2O_3$$\[\text{Hence, molecular weight of oxide} = 2 \times 60 + 3 \times 16 = 120 + 48 = 168\]

question: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
question_latex: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
solution: Law of multiple proportions is applicable for two or more elements are combined in more than one form.\n e.g.: $$\text{H}_2\text{O},\text{H}_2\text{O}_2;\text{SO}_2,\text{SO}_3; \text{NO},\text{NO}_2$$

question: An ore contains 1.34% of the mineral argentite, Ag2S, by mass. How many gram of this ore would have to be processed in order to obtain 1.00 g of pure solid silver, Ag?
question_latex: An ore contains 1.34\% of the mineral argentite, Ag_2S, by mass. How many gram of this ore would have to be processed in order to obtain 1.00 g of pure solid silver, Ag?
solution:
$$	ext{Ag}_2	ext{S} \Rightarrow 2	ext{Ag}$$\[248 	ext{ g} \Rightarrow 2 	imes 108 	ext{ g}\]\[2 	imes 108 	ext{g Ag is obtained from } 	ext{Ag}_2	ext{S} = 248 	ext{ g}\] 1 g Ag will be obtained from Ag_2S
 $$ rac{248}{2	imes108} =  rac{248	imes1}{216	ext{ g}}$$
But, the ore contains only 1.34% Ag_2S.
Thus, 1 g Ag is obtained from ore = $$ rac{248}{216}	imes  rac{100}{1.34}$$
$$= 85.68 g$$

question: A gas is found to have formula [CO]x. Its vapour density is 70, the x is
question_latex: A gas is found to have formula [CO]_x. Its vapour density is 70, the x is
solution:
Given, vapour density=70
$$	herefore$$ Molecular weight = $$2 	imes$$ vapour density
$$= 2	imes70 = 140$$
$$	ext{[CO]}_x = (12+16)x = 28x$$
$$	herefore 28x = 140$$
$$\Rightarrow x =  rac{140}{28} = 5$$
$$	herefore$$ Formula is $$	ext{(CO)}_5$$
